content.description:
This route is the longest climb on the Walrus and climbs two long pitches of beautiful and featured slab.

I have not climbed this route, and the grade is an estimate. I am posting it for historical purposes. There are no quicklinks on either set of anchors. Walk off.
content.location: Start at the lowest point on the East face.

content.description:
Climb the slabby arete.

I have not climbed, this but judging by the angle, it looks to be around this grade. I am posting it for historical purposes. This is the first route you come to.
content.location: It is on the West face before the large, open, slabby area.

content.description:
Pitch 1: layback a flake to gain the corner; clipping bolts and placing gear, to a small stance below the crux. Move past a bolt utilizing a shallow right-facing corner before stepping left onto the slab. Belay at a nice ledge, 5.10-.

Pitch 2: climb up the slab, 5.4.
content.protection:
P1: pro to 2”, 7bolts, and a 2 bolt anchor.

P2: 2 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is in the alcove right of “

Walrus Slab

.”

content.description:
Pitch 1: climb up easy slab to a thin flake, commit to a move left (crux and runout), and gain the good crack. The crack varies in size - some may want doubles in cams. Follow this to the “hidden steps” and the anchor.

Pitch 2: climb the slab to the top. Locate and belay at a left-facing flake on the summit and a single bolt in a hole, 5.5.
content.protection:
P1: pro to 3” and a 2 bolt anchor.

P2: 3 bolts, a 1 bolt anchor, and medium cams.
content.location:
Once you pass “

Tusk

,” you’ll be on an slabby oasis... look for the obvious crack line.
